last_post.content:
I am quite fed up with current state "AI" being hyped. It's so pathetic and has nothing to do with intelligence. That's just a clever marketing term, and it seems to be working :flan_sad:

Latest example is Google's MusicLM. It can create something like music from text prompts. Which is a cool feat, yes. But listen to the examples. They are so bad! Yes, you can hear what genre it's supposed do be. Yes, it's... Close to music. But it has nothing. No soul. No meaning. Not even words or melodies (!) that carry sense. It's tough to listen to more than a few seconds.

It's just probability, put to use.

It's "oh, after a sound that goes like this there's often a sound that goes like that in genre X." And frankly, for someone who loves to create and listen to music, these "songs" are close to torture in the way they defy everything I love about music.

You can find the "AI" here: https://google-research.github.io/seanet/musiclm/examples/

Something I learnt about only recently (it may have been on here): for many arxiv preprints, if you replace the "x" in the url with a "5", you will get a nice accessible html :html5: version!

example:
https://ar5iv.org/abs/2203.08489

Works quite well for reading on your phone in the train for example 👍

title: Tools such as ChatGPT threaten transparent science; here are our ground rules for their use

last_post.content:
Nature sets the right ground rules for using GPT-like tools for research papers.

1. No co-authorship since AI cannot take responsibility

2. Must acknowledge use

https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-023-00191-1

You should read @Mer__edith's thread on all this,¹ and it's worth remembering what @signalapp does and does not do.

Signal does not protect you from:
• an untrustworthy chat partner
• a compromised device
• corporate device management
• your device's Operating System

Signal does protect you from:
• a hack of the Signal servers
• a subpoena of the Signal servers
• the wire between you and the Signal servers
• the employees at Signal

¹ https://mastodon.world/@Mer__edith/109751701529562752

#Genuary26 #Genuary

Day 26: My kid could have done that

For this prompt I implemented the sinuous meander patterns of Chappell. They resemble the bug-eyed, multi-legged monsters that my kid used to draw when he was little, all spirals and curves with countless appendages.

https://doi.org/10.1080/17513472.2015.1092859

title: F1000Research Article: Current market rates for scholarly publishing services.

last_post.content:
Nice to have the Society Publishers Coalition nakedly admit (in aggregate) that the cost of publication on average is just £730, whilst revenue (pricing) per unit is on average £1,575 leaving them an average surplus of £846 per publication. Another useful data point in addition to @brembs work https://f1000research.com/articles/10-20/v2

Research papers increasingly refer to websites like GitHub for code, which may be a problem...

About 20% of preprints referred to GitHub in 2021. Yet, these web pages are often not archived, jeopardizing their long-term availability.

"The growing use of Git Hosting Platforms in scholarly publications points to an urgent and growing need for dedicated efforts to archive their holdings in order to preserve research code"

via https://doi.org/10.48550/arXiv.2208.04895

Ok, so.

Tweets look really good when you send them in Messages on iOS/macOS. Mastodon posts… don’t. So I built a little tool that makes them much nicer to look at:

https://mstdn.link

Add ?to={any Mastodon post URL} to the end of that domain and when you send it to a friend, you get the nice looking preview. Of course the page makes it easy to paste a URL in. And there’s a Shortcut to make it even easier on iOS or macOS.

Call for papers for @sti2023, a hybrid conference organized in Sep 2023 by @cwts, has been published https://www.sti2023.org/call-for-papers/.

We're excited about the new approach we're going to take to publication and peer review of conference submissions.

All submissions will immediately be published as a preprint. Peer review reports will be published as well. (Reviewers may remain anonymous.)

We hope this approach will accelerate the dissemination of new knowledge and increase the value of peer review.

Found it! It's "Bowling Alone" by Robert Putnam, which discusses the decline of American civic life. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bowling_Alone Thank you @benjacobsen & @elplatt.

I realized I learned about it from @ethanz — in the paper "How social media could teach us to be better citizens" he argues that Reddit-style content moderation could give people the community governance experience that they have lost. https://www.je-lks.org/ojs/index.php/Je-LKS_EN/article/view/1135818/1333

Personally, I find this to be the single most exciting thing about Mastodon.

Found it! It's "Bowling Alone" by Robert Putnam, which discusses the decline of American civic life. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bowling_Alone Thank you @benjacobsen & @elplatt.

I realized I learned about it from @ethanz — in the paper "How social media could teach us to be better citizens" he argues that Reddit-style content moderation could give people the community governance experience that they have lost. https://www.je-lks.org/ojs/index.php/Je-LKS_EN/article/view/1135818/1333

This is the third in my series of explorations of the training data behind various generative AI models, which also covers LAION (used by Stable Diffusion) and WebVid-10M (used by Meta's Make-A-Video) - the full series of posts is here: https://simonwillison.net/series/how-its-trained/

title: Eggplant: The Secret Lives of Games: 108: Designing For Delight with Vectorpark (Windosill)

last_post.content:
108: Designing For Delight with Vectorpark (Windosill)

@vectorpark joins us to discuss his curious and inspiring oeuvre, the lost art of Flash games and DVD menus, and the pros and cons of keeping your art to yourself.

Links to listen and show notes at:
https://eggplant.show/108-finding-games-in-art-with-vectorpark-windosill
